Citation:
Ala. Code § 8-38-1 et seq.
 Ala. Code § 27-6 (for insurance industry)
Harm Required: YES. Ala. Code § 8-38-6(a).

Citation: Alaska Stat. § 45.48.010 et seq.
Harm Required: YES. If, after investigation, entity determines there is not reasonable likelihood of harm to affected individuals, must notify AG. Alaska Stat. § 45.48.010.

Citation: Ariz. Rev. Stat. §18-551 to Ariz. Rev. Stat. §18-552
Harm Required: YES. Ariz. Rev. Stat. §18-552(J).

Citation: Ark. Code Ann. § 4-110-101 et seq., “Personal Information Protection Act”
Harm Required: YES. Ark. Code Ann. § 4-110-105(d).

Citation: Cal. Civ. Code §1798.82 (as applicable to non-governmental entities); Cal. Civ. Code §1798.29 (as applicable to governmental entities).
Harm Required: NO.

Citation: Colo. Rev. Stat. § 6-1-716. See also Colo. Rev. Stat. § 24-73-101 et seq., which applies to governmental entities.
Harm Required: YES, based on a determination that personal information “has been or will be misused.” Colo. Rev. Stat. § 6-1-716(2).

Citation: Conn. Gen. Stat. § 36a-701b.
Harm Required: YES. Conn. Gen. Stat. § 36a-701b(b)(1).

Citation:
Del. Code tit. 6, § 12B-101 et seq.
 Effective 4/14/18, Del. Code tit. 6, § 12B-100 et seq.
Harm Required: YES. Del. Code tit. 6, § 12B-102(a).

Citation:
D.C. Code § 28-3851 et seq. 
 Amended By D.C. Law 23-98, § 2, 67 DCR 3923, eff. 6/17/2020 (Security Breach Protection Amendment Act Of 2020).
Harm Required: NO. However, the 2020 Amendment created a new exception for notice if low risk of harm (not likely to harm affected individuals) after consulting with AG and federal law enforcement agencies. D.C. Code § 28-3851(1)(B)(iii)).

Citation:
Fla. Stat. § 501.171,
 the “Florida Information Protection Act of 2014.”

Harm Required: NO.

Citation: 9 Guam Code Ann. § 48.10 et seq.
Harm Required: Yes. 9 Guam Code Ann. § 48.30.

Citation: Haw. Rev. Stat. § 487N-1 et seq.
Harm Required: YES. Haw. Rev. Stat. § 487N-1.

Citation: Idaho Code § 28-51-104, Idaho Code § 28-51-105, Idaho Code § 28-51-106, Idaho Code § 28-51-107.
Harm Required: YES. Idaho Code § 28-51-105(1).

Citation: 815 Ill. Comp. Stat. 530/1 et seq., “Personal Information Protection Act”.
Harm Required: NO.

Citation: Ind. Code § 24-4.9-1-1 et seq. (applicable to non-governmental entities); Ind. Code § 4-1-11-1 et seq. (applicable to state and local agencies).
Harm Required: YES. Ind. Code § 24-4.9-3-1 (applicable to non-governmental entities); Ind. Code § 4-1-11-5 (applicable to state and local agencies).

Citation: Iowa Code § 715C.1 - Iowa Code § 715C.2.
Harm Required: YES. Iowa Code § 715C.2(6).

Citation: Kan. Stat. § 50-7a01 et seq.
Harm Required: YES. Kan. Stat. § 50-7a02(a).

Citation: Ky. Rev. Stat. § 365.720 et seq.
Harm Required: YES. Breach must have actually caused or lead the information holder to reasonably believe that it has caused or will cause, identity theft or fraud against any KY resident. Ky. Rev. Stat. § 365.732(1)(a).

Citation: La. Rev. Stat. § 51:3071 et seq., “Database Security Breach Notification Law”.
Harm Required: YES. La. Rev. Stat. § 51:3074(G). Effective 8/1/2018, La. Rev. Stat. § 51:3074(I).

Citation: Me. Rev. Stat. Ann. tit. 10, § 1346 et seq. “the Notice of Risk to Personal Data Act.”
Harm Required: YES, but for Information Broker must notify, if it finds that personal information has been/reasonably believed to have been acquired; any other individual or entity must notify if it finds that misuse has occurred/reasonably possible that it will occur. Me. Rev. Stat. Ann. tit. 10, § 1348(1).

Citation:
Md. Code Ann., Com. Law. § 14-3501 et seq.
 Md. Code, Ins. § 4-406 (insurance carriers).
Harm Required: YES. If, after investigation, entity determines personal information has not been/ is not likely to be misused, must retain documentation for 3 years. Md. Code Ann., Com. Law. § 14-3504(b)(4).

Citation: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 93H, § 1 et seq.
Harm Required: YES, per definition of breach must create a substantial risk of identity theft or fraud against a MA resident. Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 93H, § 1(a).

Citation:
Mich. Comp. Laws § 445.61 et seq.
 [For the insurance industry, Mich. Comp. Laws § 500.559 et seq.]
Harm Required: YES. Notification not required if person or agency determines that the security breach has not or is not likely to cause substantial loss or injury to, or result in identity theft with respect to MI residents. Mich. Comp. Laws § 445.72(1) - (3); Mich. Comp. Laws § 500.559(1) (insurance industry).

Citation: Minn. Stat. § 325E.61 (applicable to non-government entities); Minn. Stat. § 13.055 (applicable to government entities).
Harm Required: NO.

Citation:
Miss. Code § 75-24-29.
 2019 Miss. S.B. 2831 § 6 (for insurance industry).
Harm Required: YES, but not only maintaining data. Miss. Code § 75-24-29(3).

Citation: Mo. Rev. Stat. § 407.1500
Mont. Code § 30-14-1701 et seq.
Harm Required: YES. Definition of “breach of the security of the data system,” includes a determination that the unauthorized acquisition of computerized data “materially compromises the security, confidentiality, or integrity of personal information maintained by the person or business and causes or is reasonably believed to cause loss or injury to a Montana resident.” Mont. Code § 30-14-1704(4)(1).

Citation: Neb. Rev. Stat. § 87-801 et seq., “Financial Data Protection and Consumer Notification of Data Security Breach Act of 2006.”
Harm Required: YES. Neb. Rev. Stat. § 87-803.

Citation: Nev. Rev. Stat. § 603A.010 et seq.
Harm Required: YES, “breach of the security of the system data” is defined as the unauthorized acquisition of computerized data that materially compromises the security, confidentiality or integrity of personal information maintained by the data collector.” Nev. Rev. Stat. § 603A.020.

Citation:
N.H. Rev. Stat. § 359-C:19 et seq., “New Hampshire Right to Privacy Act.”
 For the insurance industry: N.H. Rev. Stat. § 420-P:1 et seq., “Insurance Data Security Law.”
Harm Required:
YES. N.H. Rev. Stat. § 359-C:20(I)(a).
 For the insurance industry: YES. N.H. Rev. Stat. § 420-P:6.

Citation: N.J. Rev. Stat. § 56:8-161 et seq.
Harm Required: YES - disclosure not required if company determines that misuse of information is not reasonably possible; must document determination and retain for 5 years. N.J. Rev. Stat. § 56:8-163(a).

Citation: N.M. Stat. Ann. §57-12C-1 et seq.
Harm Required: Notification is not required if, after an appropriate investigation, the data owner/licensee determines that the security breach does not give rise to a significant risk of identity theft or fraud. N.M. Stat. Ann. §57-12C-6(B).

Citation: N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 899-aa (applicable to non-governmental entities); N.Y. State Tech. § 208 (applicable to governmental entities); N.Y. Educ. Law § 2-D (applicable to educational agencies and their third-party contractors).
Harm Required:
YES - In determining whether information has been acquired, or is reasonably believed to have been acquired, by an unauthorized person or a person without valid authorization, business may consider the following factors: (1) indication that info. is in phys. possession and control of an unauthorized person, (e.g., lost or stolen computer/other device); (2) indication that info. has been downloaded/ copied; or (3) indication that info. was used by an unauthorized person (e.g., fraudulent accounts opened or identity theft reported). N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 899-aa(1)(c)(as applicable to non-governmental entities); N.Y. State Tech. § 208(1)(b) (as applicable to governmental entities).
 NO - N.Y. Educ. Law § 2-D (as applicable to state educational agencies and their third party contractors).

Citation: N.C. Gen. Stat. § 75-61 et seq. “Identity Theft Protection Act”, N.C. Gen. Stat. § 75-65.
Harm Required: YES. N.C. Gen. Stat. § 75-61(14).

Citation:
N.D. Cent. Code § 51-30-01, et seq.; N.D. Cent. Code § 54-NEW-01, et seq.
 For insurance industry, N.D. Cent. Code §§ 26.1-02-01 et. seq.
Harm Required: YES For insurance industry: notification not required if licensee determines that the security breach is not reasonably likely to materially harm a consumer residing in this state or harm any material part of the normal operations of the licensee. N.D. Cent. Code § 26.1-02.2-05(1)

Citation:
Ohio Rev. Code § 1349.19 - Ohio Rev. Code § 1349.192.
 For insurance industry: Ohio Rev. Code § 3965.01 et. seq..
Harm Required:
YES. Ohio Rev. Code § 1349.19(B)(1).
 For insurance industry: YES. Ohio Rev. Code § 3965.04(A).

Citation: Okla. Stat. tit. 24 § 161 to Okla. Stat. tit. 24 § 166 “Security Breach Notification Act”
Harm Required: YES, must cause or reasonably believed to have caused or will cause “identity theft or other fraud.” Okla. Stat. tit. 24 § 163(A).

Citation: Or. Rev. Stat. § 646A.600 et seq., “Oregon Consumer Information Protection Act.”
Harm Required: YES. Or. Rev. Stat. § 646A.604(7).

Citation: 73 Pa. Stat. § 2301 et seq., “Breach of Personal Information Notification Act”
Harm Required: YES. 73 Pa. Stat. § 2302, definition of “Breach of the security of the system.”

Citation: P.R. Laws Ann. tit. 10, § 4051 et seq.
Harm Required: No.

Citation: R.I. Gen. Laws § 11-49.3-1 et seq., “Rhode Island Identity Theft Protection Act of 2015.”
Harm Required: YES (“significant risk of identity theft”). R.I. Gen. Laws § 11-49.3-4(a)(1)

Citation: S.C. Code § 39-1-90. [For the insurance industry, S.C. Code § 38-99-10 et seq.]

Harm Required: YES; no notification required to individuals if, following appropriate investigation and notice to AG, the notifier reasonably determines that breach will not likely result in harm to affected SD residents. However, the notifier must document the determination in writing and maintain such documentation for at least 3 years. SB 62, 93rd Sess. (S.D. 2018), eff. 7/1/2018.

Citation:
Tenn. Code § 47-18-2107.
 [Applicable to state insurance licensees] Tenn. Code § 56-2-1001 et seq. (effective July 1, 2021). 2021 Tenn. Pub. Acts. Ch. 345. Insurance Data Security Law, HB 766.
Harm Required:
NO.
 For insurance licensees, there is a threshold of harm defined as “reasonable likelihood of materially harming a consumer residing the in the state or a material part of the licensee's normal operations.” Tenn. Code § 56-2-1006(a).

Citation: Tex. Bus. Com. Code § 521.002, Tex. Bus. Com. Code § 521.052, Tex. Bus. Com. Code § 521.053, Tex. Bus. Com. Code § 521.151
Harm Required: NO.

Citation: V.I. Code Ann. tit. 14, §2208 - 2212.
Harm Required: No.

Citation: Utah Code § 13-44-101 et seq., “Protection of Personal Information Act.”
Vt. Stat. tit. 9, §2430 et seq., “Security Breach Notice Act”
Harm Required: YES, but must still notify AG or Dept. of Financial Reg. of breach, even if no harm. Vt. Stat. tit. 9, §2435(b)(3)(B).

Citation:
Va. Code § 18.2-186.6.
 For insurance industry: Va. Code § 38.2-621 (et. seq.).
Harm Required: YES, must cause or reasonably believed to have caused or will cause “identity theft or other fraud.” Va. Code § 18.2-186.6(A)(definition of “Breach of the security of the system”).

Citation: Wash. Rev. Code § 19.255.010 et seq.
Harm Required: YES - must be “reasonably likely to subject consumers to a risk of harm.” Wash. Rev. Code § 19.255.010(1).

Citation: W. Va. Code § 46A-2A-101, et seq.
Harm Required: YES, “has caused or will cause identity theft or other fraud to any resident of this state.” W. Va. Code § 46A-2A-102(a).

Citation: Wis. Stat. § 134.98.
Wyo. Stat. § 40-12-501 et seq.
Harm Required: YES. Wyo. Stat. § 40-12-502(a).
